title: Query-based Linked Data Anonymization

author: Rémy Delanaux, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1

segmentation: So good afternoon everyone.
I mean there are no.
I'll be talking about query based link data anonymization which is part of my PhD work at the latest lab in Lyon, France in a joint work with the League lab in Grenoble, also in France.
So this work is set in the context of publishing the data set in the linked open Data Cloud.
Every some presenters talked about the linked open Data Cloud previously.
I think I suppose most of you know about this huge network of structured connecting datasets freely accessible on the Internet that mostly use the same standards.
For example standards for data modeling in the form of RDF graphs all stand out for date, accruing in the shape of.
Oracle queries.
Data providers, usually academics, institution nonprofits but also sometimes private company.
Usually want to add their RDF graph RDF datasets in this log cloud, but in some cases those providers may realize that they have sensitive data.
The running example will take in.
This presentation is, for example, a public transportation network.
They had usually some have already published some data such as subway lines, bus stops.
You know you know those, but they also may process subscription data like addresses of users.
The type of subscription they have subscription.

Type payment information and they might also want to publish this for statistical analysis, but obviously they cannot because they contain sensitive information, so they have to find a way to anonymize it before publishing, and they might hold constraints on what to hide, what to keep, and this is the problems we want to solve here.
So this is in fact.
Somehow, manifestation of a typical problem determine nagement, which is how to balance data privacy and data utility.
Because obviously if you have a data set you can achieve total privacy.
You just delete everything then obviously you have complete privacy, but you cannot really use it anymore.
And at the other end of the spectrum you can achieve total utility if you just don't do anything with your data.
But this is maybe also.
This may also be a problem, because if it hurt it held sensitive information in the beginning.
It would still be there in the end, so there's this whole range of possibilities.
The whole realm of possibilities.
Really, we can just do like slight modifications to ensure that the relevant data is still here, But you still want to hide some things.
Or you can do heavy modifications and it's really not clear what are the possibilities.

Part of this work is also to define which type of modifications can we make in the context of linked open data and RDF graphs, and also which compromise can we choose which balance and how do we define it?
So to solve this, our contributions were sound static and query based framework so static in the sense that we don't look at the graph's contents.
An we create the data independent solution, an algorithm associated to it to enumerate what we call candidate anonymization.
More on that later, and we'll rise simple implementation in Python an will talk about about a little about experience today.
Later on the present.
So the first main tool of our framework is called policies.
Policies are sets of queries and there are way for us to encode constraints given by the data provider.
There are two policies, one privacy policy describing what the data provider wants to hide basically, and one utility policy describing what they want to keep in the anonymized data set.
So here is again already example with the transportation network.
The privacy policy contained privacy queries so called and they must not return anything when applied when evaluated on the anonymized data set.
For example, here we have two queries and clearly the fact is we don't want those query to return results.
